lyrics:
[Verse 1]

But feelin' alone
[Refrain]

In someone's handwriting, not mine

[Pre-Chorus]

Stars all aligned and they intertwined
And taught you

Treat me like a lady
All that I can say is
[Chorus]

Now you're all I need, I'm so thankful for

But I love you more [Verse 2]
When I think of all the makeup
Fake love out on the town (Ooh)
Cryin' in the bathroom for some dude
Whose name I cannot remember now
[Refrain]
Secret jokes all alone
No one's home, sixteen and wild (Ooh)
Breakin' up, makin' up
Leave without sayin' goodbye (Ooh)
[Pre-Chorus]
And just know that
It's everything that made me
Now I call you "baby"
It's why you're so amazing
[Chorus]
All of the girls you loved before (Ooh)
Made you the one I've fallen for
Every dead-end street led you straight to me
Now you're all I need, I'm so thankful for
All of the girls you loved before
But I love you more [Bridge]
Your mother brought you up loyal and kind
Teenage love taught you there's good in goodbye
Every woman that you knew brought you here
I wanna teach you how forever feels
[Chorus]
Like the girls you loved before (Ooh)
Made you the one I've fallen for
Every dead-end street (Dead-end street) led you straight to me (Straight to me)
Now you're all I need (All I need), I'm so thankful for
All of the girls you loved before
But I love you more
[Outro]
(I love you more)
(I love you more)
annotation:
“All Of The Girls You Loved Before” is a song by Taylor Swift, intended for her seventh studio album, Lover (2019), but was not included on the final tracklist for unknown reasons.
Snippets of the song leaked online in February 2023, and the full song appeared in its entirety for the first time on March 1, 2023. On March 16, 2023, to celebrate the beginning of her 2023 The Eras Tour, Swift revealed through Instagram Stories that the song would officially be released at midnight on March 17, 2023, along with three other tracks: “Eyes Open (Taylor’s Version),” “Safe and Sound (Taylor’s Version),” featuring Joy Williams and John Paul White, and “If This Was a Movie (Taylor’s Version).”
song: All Of The Girls You Loved Before

annotation:
Swift wrote “Castles Crumbling” around 2010 for her third studio album, Speak Now. Since then, fans gained knowledge of the song, but no part of it was actually ever heard until it was released as a From The Vault track on Speak Now (Taylor’s Version) on July 7th, 2023, featuring Taylor’s long-time friend, Hayley Williams.
In June 2023, a fan gifted Hayley with a bracelet themed after Speak Now, fact to which she said that was “coming at a very interesting time.” Her reaction brought fans to speculate about her appearence on the album, which was later confirmed when Swift posted its tracklist. While announcing it, Taylor mentioned that Hayley’s band, Paramore, was a huge influence to her around the time that she wrote Speak Now.
Although “Castles Crumbling” marks their first collaboration, Hayley had already been a guest star during Swift’s 2011 Speak Now Tour, and had also made an appearence in the music video for her 2015 single, “Bad Blood.” Hayley is also heavily rumoured to have been the inspiration behind the song “Speak Now.”
Lastly, two days before the song came out, Swift revealed on Twitter that Paramore would be an opening act for several of Taylor’s The Eras Tour dates in 2024.

annotation:
“Dress” is one of Taylor’s most sexually charged songs on reputation and it details Taylor’s wants and lusts over another lover. As the name implies, many of the sexual references throughout the song pertain to dresses and the main hook of the song is something Swift herself admitted feeling really proud of. Taylor has a history of fascination with dresses dating back to her country music roots from when she first stepped foot in the music industry.
This song is most likely about Swift’s boyfriend at the time it was written, the british actor Joe Alwyn, who is also rumored to be Taylor’s muse for many other songs, especially throughout her 2017 and 2019 albums, reputation and Lover, respectively. The couple dated from 2016 until 2023 and “Dress” seems to be detailing Swift’s point of view from the beginning of their relationship — the bridge, specially, is full with references to when and how they first met.

annotation:
“Drama Queen” appears on Swift’s SONY Registry. Co-written by Martin Johnson, it was probably scrapped from 2010’s Speak Now — Johnson also helped write “If This Was a Movie,” which appeared on the album’s deluxe edition.
As noted by a fan who catalogues Swift’s unreleased tracks, the song appeared on databases around June 2009, so she probably wrote it in 2008 or early 2009.
A snippet of the song leaked in February of 2023.

annotation:
“Hits Different” was a bonus track on the Target-exclusive Midnights: Lavender Edition. However, due to requests from fans, Taylor announced on May 24, 2023 that the track would be included on Midnights (Til Dawn Edition) which released on May 26, 2023 on streaming platforms.
This track describes Taylor in a state of heartbreak that she has previously not experienced. It “hits different”, that is, it is out of the ordinary.
While Taylor has previously shunned lovers who left her such as in “White Horse” and “Picture to Burn”, here, Taylor describes a situation of struggling to move on and wanting an ex back, similar to “Death by a Thousand Cuts”.

annotation:
“Karma (Remix)” is a remix of Taylor Swift’s 2022 song “Karma” featuring rapper Ice Spice.
Swift announced the collaboration via Twitter alongside Midnights (Til Dawn Edition), featuring an extended version of “Snow On The Beach” with a new verse from Lana Del Rey.


Um. SO much to tell you. I’m a massive fan of this brilliant artist and after getting to know her I can confirm: she is THE ONE to watch. So delighted to say that Karma Featuring the incredible @icespicee_ will be out TOMORROW night at MIDNIGHT ET as a part of the new Midnights… pic.twitter.com/OaRrHBWTUw— Taylor Swift (@taylorswift13) May 24, 2023

annotation:
“Lavender Haze,” the love life-inspired opening Midnights‘ track, captures the feelings of a honeymoon-style relationship and is inspired by the classic 50’s phrase of the same name.
Inspired by a line from a Mad Men episode, Swift wrote this song to convey the desire to focus on the passion of love rather than being swayed by the negative or unwanted remarks of others.
On an October 2022 Instagram post Swift compares her 6-year relationship at the time with british actor Joe Alwyn to the themes of the song, stating:
I think a lot of people have to deal with this now, not just ‘public figures’, because we live in the era of social media. If the world finds out that you’re in love with somebody, they’re going to weigh in on it. Like my relationship, for six years we’ve had to dodge weird rumors, tabloid stuff, and we just ignore it.
The track was unveiled in Taylor’s TikTok game show, Midnight Mayhem With Me.

[Chorus]

It was maroon
annotation:
“Maroon” is the second song on Taylor Swift’s tenth album Midnights. It has similarities to “Red” and “Clean.”
While “Red” describes a love that was “burning red,” this track is a more grown-up version of a love story. It shows that shades of red were a constant in the relationship, but maroon is a brownish crimson color; it is not a straightforward red but allows for complexities and honesty.

lyrics:
[Intro]
Rain
He wanted it comfortable, I wanted that pain
He wanted a bride, I was making my own name
Chasing that fame, he stayed the same
All of me changed like midnight
[Verse 1]
My town was a wasteland
Full of cages, full of fences
Pageant queens and big pretenders
But for some, it was paradise
My boy was a montage
A slow-motion, love potion
Jumping off things in the ocean
I broke his heart 'cause he was nice
He was sunshine, I was midnight rain
[Chorus]
He wanted it comfortable, I wanted that pain
He wanted a bride, I was making my own name
Chasing that fame, he stayed the same
All of me changed like midnight
[Verse 2]
It came like a postcard
Picture perfect shiny family
Holiday peppermint candy
But for him, it's every day
So I peered through a window
A deep portal, time travel
All the love we unravel
And the life I gave away
'Cause he was sunshine, I was midnight rain [Chorus]
He wanted it comfortable, I wanted that pain
He wanted a bride, I was making my own name
Chasing that fame, he stayed the same
All of me changed like midnight rain
He wanted it comfortable, I wanted that pain
He wanted a bride, I was making my own name
Chasing that fame, he stayed the same
All of me changed like midnight
[Outro]
I guess sometimes we all get
Just what we wanted, just what we wanted
And he never thinks of me
Except for when I'm on TV
I guess sometimes we all get
Some kind of haunted, some kind of haunted
And I never think of him
Except on midnights like this
(Midnights like this, midnights like this)
annotation:
With the song utilizing an inside light pop rhythm with a mix of some synth sounds, “Midnight Rain” finds Taylor singing about ending a relationship to focus on her singing career more. It then ends off, with their relationship being forgotten, as if it never happened.
The song also reflects on a relationship where the two were opposites of each other, in which this case is “Sunshine” and “Midnight rain”. Each wants something different out of the relationship and has different expectations.

I won't leave (I won't leave), it's a need (Oh)
annotation:
“Need” is an alleged reject from Swift’s August 2019 album, which the infamous group Taylor’s Inner Circle obtained in March 2020. The group describes the song, saying:
The music is unlike any other Taylor song with the chords played in a unique way starting and stopping (sometimes with vocal effects added over). Taylor gives fascinating insight into her thoughts on want, desire, passion, lust, danger, and fear. What Taylor needs most is to be with the man she loves. It’s essential, like breathing for her. The music is stripped down during the bridge. A really good song that would have fit well on the album and perhaps been a fan favorite.
The song appeared online in its entirety on March 1st, 2023

annotation:
Reflecting upon a past relationship on “Question…?,” Swift asks her former lover if their newer romantic experiences compare to the time that they spent together. Implicitly, she hopes that their ex is similarly unable to move on from her and that their newer attempts at love are only “second best after that meteor strike.”
The track opens with an interpolation from “Out of the Woods,” off of Swift’s 1989 album. Like “Question…?,” “Out of the Woods” is a song looking back on the memories of a now-dead relationship.

“Say Don’t Go” presents a heartfelt narrative of longing and heartbreak. The second vault track from Taylor Swift’s re-released version of 1989, it delves into the complexities of a relationship, where the protagonist feels vulnerable and uncertain. Painting a picture of emotional turmoil, including feelings of sadness, anxiety, and longing, the song encapsulates the desire for the other person to stay, juxtaposed with the pain of feeling led on, ignored and left behind.
The song was released on October 27, 2023, along with the rest of 1989 (Taylor’s Version).
song: Say Don’t Go (Taylor’s Version) [From The Vault]

annotation:
In “Snow On the Beach”, Taylor Swift and Lana Del Rey sing about the rare phenomenon of two lovers simultaneously falling in love with each other. The song’s heart-warming lyrics are part of a light and dreamy track that compliment the duo’s heavenly vocals.
Ahead of its release, Swift explained the meaning behind “Snow On the Beach” on Instagram, and also expressed feeling “grateful for life” to get to collaborate for the first time with Del Rey, whom she called “one of the best musical artists ever” and admitted being a “massive fan” of hers, although not the first the time, since Taylor had already voiced her admiration for Lana’s work in the past.
“Snow on the Beach” was the final Midnights track to be announced on Midnights Mayhem with Me. Swift revealed the title of the song, and Lana Del Rey being featured on it, during the final episode of her TikTok series.
Rumors of the duo’s highly-anticipated collaboration first sparked in April 2022, after Lana Del Rey shared a picture of her next to Swift and producer Jack Antonoff, a mutual collaborator of both singers, presumed to be the link between them working together.
Upon “Snow On the Beach”’s release, Swift received criticism from fans and the media for continuing to relegate female artists featured in her songs, and not meeting the expectations of a duet with Del Rey, one of the biggest female artists of 2022.
As a consequence, a new version of the song was released on Taylor’s Til Dawn album reedition issued in May 2023, with one of the verses sung by Lana instead.

annotation:
Answering to many fans and their wish for Lana Del Rey to take on a more prominent role in “Snow on the Beach,” Taylor Swift got back together in the studio with her co-star to re-record a new version of the Midnights track.
Upon its original release, “Snow on the Beach” received a mixed response among fans and critics due to the fact that Taylor didn’t give Del Rey her own verse and relegated her to only sing background vocals, which made her join a list of previous Swift collaborators (The Chicks, HAIM) that suffered the same fate.
On February 7, 2023, Lana shared on Instagram that before recording their collaboration, she had no prior knowledge of becoming the only featured artist on Midnights, and stated that she “would’ve sung the entire second verse if [she] had known.”
Announced on May 24, this “More Lana Del Rey” version of “Snow on the Beach” is included on the Til Dawn edition of Swift’s tenth studio album, issued seven months after Midnights‘ release, along with a remix of “Karma” and the arrival of “Hits Different” to streaming platforms.
song: Snow On The Beach (feat. More Lana Del Rey)

lyrics:

[Chorus]

And if I'm gonna be drunk

Takin’ your time in the tangerine
Neon light, this is luxury

But you're goin' to
Half awake
Takin' your chance, it's a big mistake
I said, 
"It might blow up in your pretty face"
I'm not sayin', "Do it anyway" (Do it anyway)
But you're going to [Outro]
(Up)
And if they call me a (Slut)

annotation:
“Slut!” leans fully into Swift’s media reputation as a “slut,” accepting that branding as long as it means she’s dating “the one.” The song, the first From The Vault track from 1989 (Taylor’s Version), was ostensibly written around 2013-14, a time where Swift frequently embraced the negative media portrayal she got in her lyrics – perhaps most notably in “Blank Space.”
Taylor originally teased the track via a video she  posted to her Instagram account on September 19, 2023. The video features a vault with the letters and symbols of the track title coming out of it. Taylor would reveal the full tracklist on September 20, 2023, and the song released with the rest of 1989 TV on October 27, 2023.

lyrics:
[Verse 1]
You had people who called you on unmarked numbers
In my peripheral vision
I let it slide like a hose on a slippery plastic summer
All was quickly forgiven
You were so magnetic, it was almost obnoxious
Flush with the currency of cool
I was always turnin' out my empty pockets
And when it came to you
[Chorus]
I didn't come here to make friends
We were born to be suburban legends
When you hold me, it holds me together
And you kiss me in a way that's gonna screw me up forever
[Verse 2]
I had the fantasy that maybe our mismatched star signs
Would surprise the whole school
When I ended up back at our class reunion
Walkin' in with you
You'd be more than a chapter in my old diaries
With the pages ripped out
I am standin' in a 1950s gymnasium
And I can still see you now [Chorus]
I didn't come here to make friends
We were born to be suburban legends
When you hold me, it holds me together
And you kiss me in a way that's gonna screw me up forever
I know that you still remember
We were born to be national treasures
When you told me we'd get back together
And you kissed me in a way that's gonna screw me up forever
[Outro]
Tick-tock on the clock, I pace down your block
I broke my own heart 'cause you were too polite to do it
Waves crash on the shore, I dash to the door
You don't knock anymore and my whole life's ruined
Tick-tock on the clock, I pace down your block
I broke my own heart 'cause you were too polite to do it
Waves crash to the shore, I dash to the door
You don't knock anymore and I always knew it
That my life would be ruined
annotation:
“Suburban Legends" paints a vivid picture of a powerful relationship. The lyrics capture moments of magnetic attraction and the complexities of love. The chorus resonates with a sense of destiny, acknowledging that some bonds are destined for greatness, even amidst heartache, and reaffirms the profound impact of this connection on the protagonist’s life.
The song’s outro portrays the passage of time and the emotional turmoil that accompanies it. Swift skillfully employs imagery of a ticking clock, crashing waves, and the absence of a familiar knock to convey a sense of loss and longing.
The song was released on October 27, 2023, alongside the other vault tracks.

lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Draw the cat eye sharp enough to kill a man
You did some bad things, but I'm the worst of them
Sometimes I wonder which one'll be your last lie
They say looks can kill and I might try
I don't dress for women
I don't dress for men
Lately, I've been dressin' for revenge
[Chorus]
I don't start shit, but I can tell you how it ends
Don't get sad, get even
So on the weekends
I don't dress for friends
Lately, I've been dressin' for revenge
[Verse 2]
She needed cold, hard proof, so I gave her some
She had the envelope, where you think she got it from?
Now she gets the house, gets the kids, gets the pride
Picture me thick as thieves with your ex-wife
And she looks so pretty
Drivin' in your Benz
Lately, she's been dressin' for revenge
[Chorus]
She don't start shit, but she can tell you how it ends
Don't get sad, get even
So on the weekends
She don't dress for friends
Lately, she's been dressing for revenge [Bridge]
Ladies always rise above
Ladies know what people want
Someone sweet and kind and fun
The lady simply had enough
[Verse 3]
While he was doin' lines and crossin' all of mine
Someone told his white-collar crimes to the FBI
And I don't dress for villains
Or for innocents
I'm on my vigilante shit again
[Chorus]
I don't start shit, but I can tell you how it ends
Don't get sad, get even
So on the weekends
I don't dress for friends
Lately, I've been dressin' for revenge
annotation:
“Vigilante Shit” follows the topic of a woman who’s seeking revenge. Swift and the subject of the song ostensibly obtain their revenge – instead of getting sad, they get even.
The themes of this song heavily parallels Swift 2020’s track “no body, no crime”, which also sees her involved in vigilantism.
Musically, this song continues with heavy synths reverberating, never quite building to its climax. The sultry, building tune creates a dreamy atmosphere similar to that of “Dress” or “Call It What You Want”, but the subject matter is considerably darker.
